“A Mask for Every Utahn” is a state of Utah initiative, in partnership with the Utah Manufacturers Association, to help Utahns who may not have a face mask and are returning to the workplace or going out in public.

The mask initiative is for all Utahns. We would particularly welcome orders from those who:

Don't already have a face mask,

Aren't able to make a face mask or get one from someone else, and

Aren't able to purchase a face mask.

The state will provide one mask to each resident who needs one, and will mail — upon request, once, and free of charge — up to six masks to each Utah mailing address. Additional details are provided below the order form. You can find a list of FAQs here.

Questions? mask@utah.gov

Spring is just around the corner but it is still flu season in Moab. It is important to adhere to the following guidelines to help keep students and staff healthy and prevent the spread of infections. Please keep your student home from school if he/she has:

• A fever >100.4. Students should be fever-free for 24 hours without the use of Tylenol or Ibuprofen before returning to school.
• A contagious illness, such as the flu
• Vomited within the past 24 hours
• Experienced diarrhea within the past 24 hours
• A body rash with itching or fever
• A diagnosis of a bacterial infection, such as bronchitis or strep throat. In such cases, keep a child home for 24 hours after starting antibiotics.

January 8 at 3:00 PM ·

On the afternoon of 7 January 2020 the Moab City Police Department was alerted to a potential threat posted on social media by a Grand County Middle School student. Our SRO, Det. Burraston, immediately initiated an investigation. He was able to identify the involved student and quickly made contact with him and his parents. An interview was conducted with the student and it was determined that the student published the social media post as a "joke". No threat exists at any Grand County school and no one is or was in danger at any time.

We take all threats of violence seriously, especially those directed toward one of our area schools. All threats will be fully investigated and when applicable, charges will be filed.

The officers failed to communicate with local law enforcement and instead began to prepare for their operation in a school parking lot. Law enforcement and educators became aware of the activity and immediately initiated emergency procedures, placing all district schools on lock down. Officers from the Utah Highway Patrol, Moab City Police Department, Grand County Sheriff’s Office and the National Park Service responded and contacted the federal agents, identified the error and determined that there was no threat to the community. Officers maintained communication with the school district during the incident and all operations have been returned to normal.

Last week, the Utah State Board of Education voted in favor of dropping physical education, arts, health, and career and college readiness classes from the required middle school curriculum. At this time, we do not anticipate any changes to the programming at GCMS as a result of that decision. We believe that a school experience rich with arts and physical activity is an important part of educating well-rounded individuals, and we've worked hard to ensure that our class offerings reflect that belief.

However, in the event that the State Legislature decides to adjust school funding in response to the recent change (a decision that would likely be made next spring), we may need to consider some changes. Yesterday, we launched SafeUT, a crisis intervention app, for students throughout the district. The app is available for both Android and Apple users, free, and easy to use. We hope that it will give kids a chance to reach out for help when they feel like they don't have anyone to talk to. It also serves as a tip line for students to report potentially harmful acts they've either witnessed or experienced.

For students without access to a smartphone or tablet, there is a link to the tip line on the school district website, as well as the main page for each of the schools.
